Review Content:
I bought the V11 for a vacation house that is currently under construction both inside and out. Read that as I have contractors walking down a dirt driveway (muddy in rain) into the house carrying all manner of power tools and product. The whole house is either hardwood floor or tile with a set of stairs. Estimate 1800 -> 2000 square feet and the contractors are in every square foot of this place. Plumbing, electric, carpentry, you name it... it's all ending up on the floor.

The V11 is awesome, I have shown it absolutely no mercy, this thing has been taking an absolute beating picking up rocks and dirt from the driveway, all types of wire clippings, wood chips sheet rock dust, packing material, you name it... if it's on the floor, it's in the dirt catcher of the V11. I probably should be using a shop vac.

The power head works extremely well on both the entry way rugs that take the first steps from the driveway into the house as well as the hardwood without having to change a power head. I either use the powerhead or the brush attachment on the stairs, depending on how bad they are.

I easily get through the whole house on a full charge, and that includes spending time on those entry way matts, and there is still some juice left.

My wife has an issue with the weight of it for a full house cleaning, it's a bit heavy for her for that length of time, but she loves the way it works when she is just doing a couple of rooms or areas at a clip and now wants one for our primary residence.

The wall hanger it comes with is useful; the hanger is both a charging station and attachment caddy in one. Odd, they don't provide a space for the small power head that comes with the vacuum.

As mentioned, the device has some weight and when you set it into the wall hanger, that weight transfers right to the screws holding it to the wall hanger to the wall, making the drywall anchors that come with the wall hanger insufficient. You need to hit a stud with the screws or use a Molly or Toggle anchor if you expect that wall hanger to stay on the wall.

It could use a headlamp on the power head, that would really be a good feature to add.

Overall, a must buy!!

Review Title: Great investment! Better than my 3 other vacs combined.
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2025
Review Content:
I am not one to hock products online, and, even with a 30% off Prime Day deal, it wasn’t cheap for a light-weight stick vacuum ($399), but, holy smokes, do I love my new cordless Dyson V11. I hate vacuuming, but I also hate visible dirt , crumbs, and dust on our rugs and floors. My family would tell you I’m a bit obsessive about it - and very annoying to them, I’m sure. To ease my stress, I invested in a self-emptying Roomba earlier this year (I wrote about that, too), with the intention of running it every other day or so. This was a reasonable solution and has been generally helpful. But I don’t remember to do it often enough, it is very slow, it scares the cat, and it doesn’t give a deep clean on our wool rugs. And when there’s a small mess, it doesn’t work to say, “Google, tell the Roomba to vacuum only the rug in the living room.” But I’ve mainly been relying on “Roberto” once a week or so, followed by a deep clean by our house cleaner once a month. She came just 2 days ago and vacuumed, swept, and mopped the whole house (using her sturdy Oreck vacuum on the rugs). God bless that woman.

But I noticed a bit of a mess on one of the rugs today, so I whipped out the brand new Dyson, which was not fully charged, to try it out. I started with the front door mat, ‘cause I was there, and it immediately got that black mat perfectly clean - something it hasn’t been since its first day, because it’s ultra-grippy and resists the suction of all other vacuums. Then I vacuumed our heavy wool black-and-cream hallway rug that tends to get bits embedded in the weave. Perfect. Then I did the 20+ year old black botanical patterned wool living room rug, which came out looking better than it has in years, and didn’t require using additional tools (e.g. a Birkenstock) to scrape up the cat fur. Without making any adjustments, I then ran it over all the hard floors on the first floor, including the thick foam kitchen anti-fatigue mat, none of which had no real visible dirt or dust apart from the odd stray crumb or litter bead. It was super quick, and easy. Definitely heavier than my old corded stick vacuum, but not uncomfortable. And I found that cordless was a much bigger convenience than I’d anticipated. I realized that I used the prior stick vac so seldom in part because I hated wrangling with the cord, unwrapping, wrapping, plugging in here and there, etc. Yes, I’m lazy when it comes to vacuuming. In any case, doing most of the first floor of our house (about 7-800SF - I admit I didn’t do the nooks and crannies or move all the furniture) took me only a few minutes and the best (or worst?) part was that this small area, which was basically “clean” to start with, filled half of the canister with dust, fur and debris I hadn’t seen. Like a LOT. Yikes.

I’ve now given away our two other (non-robotic) vacuums. The first was a massive Dyson upright that I bought used several years ago that was powerful but so heavy and hard to maneuver that we seldom used it. The other was a corded Shark stick vac that was lightweight and did well reaching under furniture and for all kinds of other uses (furniture, drapes, ceiling cobwebs, etc.), but was not as powerful as we needed for regular jobs. And lately, it had started dumping a little pile of dirt at the end of each use that needed to be swept up. My new Dyson is the perfect alternative. I’m a convert.

I've been wanting a cordless, small-frame vacuum for years. I've had a rather bulky, regular vacuum for awhile, but my house doesn't have a lot of space to maneuver in. So, we saved up and got this guy. I'll be honest, I didn't follow the directions. I took it out of the box and immediately wanted to see if it could handle my house full of cat and rabbit hair. Well, I looked at the handle and it said to charge it fully before first use... After I had used it for 20 minutes. It wasn't really picking anything up after a bit. The container was full, so I emptied it, but it still wouldn't pick anything up. I let it charge, thinking that's all it was, but then after several hours, it still wasn't picking up. I thought, "great, I broke it after 20 minutes!" Nope, I just didn't follow the directions. You have to pick a language on the handle screen first, and then it'll let you change the power setting. I realized that I had clogged it with all the hair and shredded rope toys keeping it on the middle strength setting, so I spent a while trying to pull it all out. After I found out about the power settings, though, I cranked it up to max (it only has 3 settings) and WOW what a difference!! It picks up absolutely everything.

I know some reviews talk about how bad it is that it has a pull trigger to turn it on instead of a switch, but this is actually a plus for me. Review Title: Great second vacuum, but not perfect
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2023
Review Content:
Let me start off my saying this isn't my primary vacuum. For that, I have a Miele C2+. However, that can be hard to maneuver and is a burden for small, quick messes or cleaning between deep vacuuming. Also second disclosure, I've only used this on its default setting of "medium" so anything I mention about battery life will not discuss the different power settings.

So with that said, the Dyson V11 is a good addition to the fleet and a good second vacuum. I have a smallish house so I could see vacuuming maybe half of it on medium power; most of the house is carpet, though, so I don't think using the light setting would get things clean enough. With two dogs that both shed a decent amount, I usually fill the canister to its "max fill" line every time I vacuum so keep that in mind if you have shedding pets. Could you theoretically jam more in there before emptying it? Absolutely. However, I don't know if that would cause damage or just make emptying the bin that much harder. Now, because I mentioned the bin, let's move on to that. Overall, it's pretty easy to empty: pull off whatever attachment you're using, point the end over a trashcan, and engage the red lever on the bottom of the bin. Simple, right? Well, not so fast: remember how I said I have dogs? Yeah, their fur and my wife's long hair both tend to get stuck on I'm not even sure what, meaning I have to reach in and pull out part of whatever is in the bin. Most of it slides out easily, but not everything as Dyson's advertising claims. I have a much older Dyson stick vac, maybe first or second gen (doesn't really work much anymore), and the V11 is definitely easier to empty. Just not as "point and shoot" as Dyson would have you believe. Maybe if you don't have pets or long hair.

I like how on this generation of stick vac, the power head actually has a motor in it. My old one spun the carpet beater on the vacuum's suction, which caused it to stop quite frequently. The downside is that it doesn't have a mode where you're not running the beater, like on hard floors. This doesn't really bother me much because my hard floors consist of peel-and-stick tiles and laminate "wood." I'm not sure if the beater could scratch read wood floors, but I doubt it. From what I've been able to observe, nothing seems to get wound around the beater; it's well-designed in that way. Maybe the errant long thread/string from something, but hairs and such at least don't get wrapped around it. Another downside to the carpet head is that when the beater knocks around things that for whatever reason don't get sucked up, it gets spewed around the room. My Miele includes a rubber bar to minimize this from happening: it's not perfect, but it's better than nothing.

As far as maneuverability and weight, both are pretty solid, much better than my canister vac and easy for my kids to use (both kids are under 11). It's not quite as easy to maneuver the power head as I'd like, but it's much better than the old one I have. I'd hoped it would be a bit lighter than it is, but I guess I would've needed to step up a few models to the V15 my parents have to get it lighter (wasn't about to pay over $700 for a "second" vacuum).

The other attachments that accompany the vacuum seem good, but I haven't used them. The two crevice-like tools (one is a proper crevice tool) are pretty standard. There's also a smaller motor brush I could envision using on stairs, a couch, or in a car, but I've used the regular floor tool on my stairs with no issue, but each staircase has at most 6 stairs so that's easier than if I had a bigger staircase.

Overall, I feel like the Dyson V11 is a good buy. I bought this on sale during Black Friday for maybe $350US. I'm not sure off the top of my head what it's regular cost is, but anything more than what I paid would eat into its value proposition.

Review Title: The Dyson V11: A Probably Too Long Review
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2024
Review Content:
Our old Rocket vacuum needed replacing after 8 years, so I jumped on the holiday sale on the Dyson V11. I’ve used it for a couple weeks now, and I HAVE NOTES.

• The important bit: It sucks. The vacuum’s suction is very good. Especially compared to my old Rocket. (I cleaned and maintained the filters on the old vacuum, but it could not provide the suction the V11 does.)
•Packaging: Oh my god, so much packaging! It’s a Russian nesting doll of packaging. The vacuum itself is inside a box which is inside another box which is inside a shipping box. But wait… inside that last box? More boxes! Every single piece and attachment is packed inside its own box or nestles in an intricate support structure of cardboard. I mean, the pieces surely aren’t going to get damaged, but …so much packaging.
• The Battery: Good new and bad news. It’s convenient to not have to stop to plug the old corded Rocket into a different outlet 4-5 times during vacuuming. The charging stand the V11 comes with makes it easy to recharge (if you can locate the stand near an outlet for the charging cord). HOWEVER, you get about 25 minutes of vacuuming time (at the recommended, medium power setting) on a full charge. For a four bedroom family home, that is not going to be enough! I’d rather have to move a cord and get it done all in one go. Recharge time is a couple hours.
• The "Motorbar cleaning head" (the brush roller), designed to not get tangled with hair and string, works like a charm. I normally vacuum up a lot of long hair and dental floss, but not a strand stuck in the V11’s roller.
• The handle: The design of the handle is unexpectedly not ergonomical. Being aligned at 90 degrees to the shaft makes the V11 more difficult to push *forward* as your hand is naturally pushing more towards the floor. More importantly, there is a seam in the plastic casing of the vacuum body right above the trigger. The top of your finger will rub against this seam constantly. It will rub a sore on top of your finger.
• The trigger: Some people have complained about having to hold down the trigger to keep the vacuum running. I expected to have a problem with this, but I didn’t. Just holding the V11 in a normal way rests your finger on the trigger during use, and it’s so sensitive that I seldom release it accidentally. (The sensitivity is actually almost a problem, I sometimes accidentally trigger the vacuum just handling it.)
• Length: It’s important. The grip of the V11’s handle is about 40" from the floor. The handle of my old Rocket was 42". As a 6’2" older person, I have to bend a little more than I like to vacuum with the V11. Most people probably won’t have that problem.
• Other notes: Because of physics, dust spinning around the inside of the plastic canister generates static electricity. If you touch the plastic casing during operation, you can get a little shock. Also, when removing the shaft and brush head to empty the dust canister, the shaft/head won’t stand up by itself for you (something my old Rocket would do), it just falls over.

In conclusion, I kind of wish my old Rocket still did the job, but at the end of the day, the Dyson V11 has superior vacuuming capability, and that’s what you need. It has some pleasant features and some mildly annoying drawbacks, but it’s worth the holiday price.

Review Title: A few drawbacks, but overall a good vacuum
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2024
Review Content:
I've just had this a week and it suctions well and is lightweight. Also, very maneuverable. So, it works well as a vacuum cleaner on both carpeted and hard surfaces (use the "MED" setting). The battery stayed charged for a whole hour or more. It's very convenient for vacuuming and I don't want to return it, but it has some surprising drawbacks due to poor planning in my opinion.

Here are the drawbacks.
1. There is NO on/off switch. As long as the battery is attached, if you barely touch the trigger the motor turns on, and it's extremely easy to touch the trigger without meaning to. So you must learn to be careful when holding it or carrying it.
2. This device is packaged with a LOT of cardboard boxes folded into various shapes to hold the components. I mean, there must have been ten or fifteen of these, which I flattened so I could recycle them. You have to see it to believe it. It's environmentally friendly, but very cumbersome to unpackage and dispose of all that cardboard.
3. You get a single sheet with a diagram that explains how to assemble it, but there are very few words and the diagrams are not detailed enough in some cases. You can download an online instruction manual, which is a lot more wordy, but it still doesn't explain everything. I found one item in the box that looks like a plastic tab and I cannot find any explanation of its function or where it goes. I just hope I don't ever need it.
4. You get a mounting plate for mounting the vacuum, but I don't know why it's in two parts that snap together with a hinge. I don't know the purpose of the hinge and it makes the mount more fragile so it could break from the weight. The screws they supply for mounting it are about two inches long, which is much much longer than necessary and I had to use two of my own shorter one inch screws to keep them from poking out the back of a wall panel. Also, why does the mounting plate fold?
5. In order to hang up the vacuum using the mounting plate, the battery must be installed. So you can't charge the battery while the vacuum is mounted, unless you have a very nearby outlet and you can't store the battery separately if you want to mount the vacuum.
6. The vacuum cleaner will not stand up on its own. There's no way to let go of it without it falling. You must lay it down or lean it against a corner where it is constrained. While vacuuming the house there are many times you want to pause and leave the vacuum in the current spot, but you must lay it down or find a corner. I don't know if other cordless vacuums have this problem, but I sure wish it could be stood up in an upright position.

It has some trouble picking up "large" debris on the floor, stuff like small pebbles or kibble sized bits. Seems to want to fling those around rather than pick them up. Its not a huge deal, but just something I thought worth mentioning. For hairs, dust, and dirt, it's awesome.

Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2025
Review Content:
I would give this 3.5 stars, and that rating is at a price much lower than the what it's currently listed at. I paid $399. I'd tried the v15 at my office after I made a mess and needed to borrow it from the cleaner. I was impressed and decided to buy one. After watching a lot of reviews, the newer version didn't seem worth the price difference and I decided to get this one. Basically, the suction is not much better on the v15 than this. The battery life is better on the v15 and there are some additional features. If you go much older than the v11, there is a bigger deterioration in suction power, so this version seems like the sweet spot for savings and suction.

The suction on this is great for a cordless and almost as good as my big vacuum. The noise level is impresively low relative to the suction power. I find the long tube very difficult to remove. The charge time is ok and the battery life is pretty good and adequate for my home. The ergonomics are terrible. Even though it's light overall, it's so top heavy that it feels really unpleasant. After using it only a few minutes, my hand starts to ache. I bought a handy little clip to hold the switch in place. It would be even more annoying to use if I had to hold the switch the whole time.

I live in an 800 sf apartment. The Dyson is ok for that and it's good for stairs. I wouldn't want to use it for a large home or as a primary vacuum even in my small apartment. If light weight and portability are a priority for you or you have a bunch of extra money to spend on the convenience of a second vaccum that's cordless, this is good for that. I don't think it's good enough to be a primary vacuum, especially for this kind of money. If I could only afford one floor vacuum for my home, I'd stick with my big old Bissell and get a Dustbuster for stairs and my car.

Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2025
Review Content:
In terms of pure performance this is a fantastic vacuum, but the ergonomics aren’t great, and it has the worst possible trigger design which has really soured me on the entire brand.

The suction and cleaning head are great; when I first got it I was downright shocked at how much dirt it sucked up from carpets that were as clean as my old plug-in vacuum—which wasn’t terrible—could get them. It definitely has no trouble getting hard floors, low-pile carpet, or medium-pile carpet clean.

It does require a fair amount of force on medium pile carpet, but the brush head auto-adjusts well which is nice. Battery life isn’t great, but is sufficient, so no real complaints there either.

Ergonomically it is fairly heavy, and because all the weight is on the end where the handle is, it feels heavier than it seems like it should. Tolerable, but vacuuming a whole house is definitely a workout compared to a plug-in canister vacuum or upright.

The main problem though is the trigger. For one thing, you need to hold it down to keep the vacuum on, which gets amazingly tiring—my grip is not up to this thing. I eventually bought a little clip-on doodad designed for exactly this—it holds the trigger on for you. But the fact that people are manufacturing add-on trigger locks for these vacuum tells you that the design is fundamentally bad to start with. It’s not, after all, a weedwhacker where having it shut off if you let go is a necessary safety feature—every other vacuum manufactured for the past century or more just switches on and stays on.

Worse still, the interior mechanism of the trigger is not durable, and cracked after a year or so of use, resulting in the vacuum either not turning on or not turning off(!) sporadically. The Internet tells me this is a VERY common failure mode. Worse still, although it’s easy to buy replacement parts here on Amazon (again, how common and readily they are does not speak well to Dyson’s quality), replacing it requires dismantling the entire vacuum—the most fragile part in the device is the hardest to replace.

This switch is so poorly designed, and so hard to repair, that it’s enough to make me into a conspiracy nut believing it’s Dyson’s way of ensuring the vacuum only lasts a couple of years and will be hard enough to repair most people won’t.

Review Title: Love Dyson products but this one falls just a bit short
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2023
Review Badge: Amazon Vine Customer Review of Free Product
Review Content:
First, I want to say I’m an avid Dyson fan. I had the first Dyson ball when it came out and have always loved Dyson. So I had high expectations for this product as Dyson is a quality brand.

Pros: suction power is good. It is lightweight and easy to maneuver. The different attachments are nice to have and they work well. Easy to charge with the wall mount. Nice and long cord.

Cons: it is a beast to clean. If anything gets clogged it is hard to get unclogged/cleaned out. The floor attachment head gets dirty easily and again, difficult to clean. The way you empty the canister makes it hard to clean inside the canister area.
Installing the wall mount: what. A. Nightmare. For such a high end company, you’d think they’d send quality drywall anchors. No. They sent the cheapest, bottom of the line anchors I’ve ever seen, and I’ve seen a lot. I ended up throwing them away (because they only sent two, no extras, and both of them broke right away), and getting some higher quality ones out of my tool kit. Dyson, do better with your anchoring system. Add in the instructions what size bit to use to drill for the anchors. Have quality anchors, and send at least one extra in case of damaged anchors. You’re hanging up a $500 vacuum, you want it to not fall off your wall.

You have to hold the button down the entire time you’re using it. I have a cheaper one for my RV, and it has a button switch that you push over for keep on. Ergonomically speaking, holding a button down the entire time is not comfortable.

It doesn’t stand on its own. Most stick vacs do. I have a Tineco and the cheaper version and they both stand up on their own with the floor attachments. This does not.

Honestly, my Tineco does just as good of a job, if not better in some areas.

Review Title: Great Suction And Capacity But Missing Key Features
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2023
Review Badge: Amazon Vine Customer Review of Free Product
Review Content:
This is my first Dyson product and the quality of this stick vac is really good, but it was missing key features that for me are very important. So out of the box you get the vacuum itself, 2 different cleaning heads one small and one large, extension wand, multipurpose attachment, crevice tool, charging adapter, cradle to hang the vacuum on a wall, and operating instructions.

The biggest positive for this machine is the power, it has really powerful suction, so this does really well on carpets, pet hair, and bigger messes. Another nice thing is the bigger dust bin, it has a large capacity and I found myself not having to empty it as often like other vacs I have used. The maneuverability is excellent, and it almost lays completely flat making it easier to get under things.

I also found the runtime to be acceptable, with the lowest eco power giving me close to an hour of vacuuming. The charge time was also pretty good, with a fully discharged battery it took between 4 to 5 hours to charge.

Unfortunately this stick is missing key features that I find are must haves. The first thing is the power switch, instead of having a regular on and off switch, you have to hold the button in while you are vacuuming, when you let go of the button the stick stops. This is just annoying, I would rather have a regular button that I can just switch on and off.

One thing that is missing on this unit is a light on the cleaning head, I find that having a light spotlights the dirt and makes it easier to clean up, so that was a major disappointment. Lastly, this unit does not stand on its own so you have to lean it against something so it won't fall. This vac is also pretty top heavy because of the bigger motor, so I would not exactly consider this unit lightweight, not real heavy, but not light.

Review Title: Life Changing to Cut the Cord... BUT MIGHT NOT HOLD UP LONG TERM
Review Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2025
Review Content:
UPDATE:
Bumping this down to 2 stars and really sad to do it (look at my initial elation below). I don't totally blame the product but the fact of the matter is I had it for a few months and somehow the cyclone ended up cracked (I have a house with 3 kids and often 2-3+ extra kids).... it is far more delicate than it should be IMHO. The cyclone plastic is like eggshell thickness.. couldn't believe it. Dyson's answer to our ask for help was to want $120 more for a cyclone unit. My husband probably could fix the unit if they gave the individual part that broke but they don't sell that. So here we are 3 months in with a BRICK. I don't really find that acceptable for an item they are asking $450-650 for on here. I really wish i started out with a refurb unit that costs half as much. We cannot afford to pay this much for a vacuum and then pay that much to repair 3 months later. Old shark corded vac lasted over 5 years and is now being put back into use.... let that speak for itself.

ORIGINAL:
My wife really enjoyed her corded shark and didn't see the point in getting one of these......... Now she freely admits that she loves it. It is so convenient that there is no reason NOT to vacuum up the little messes. Hung it in the hallway and grab it many times when i walk past. Our dogs make little "tumbleweeds" of hair... no more do i have to cringe seeing them accumulate in a corner. The attachments are awesome and i used the ol 3d printer to make additional mounts (and soon other attachments too). Cord length for the charger was pretty much perfect for us. The dustbin is of a good size to hold a full sweeping session and be dumped out (which is also super convenient once you get used to it. This thing is super handy.... I've even taken to using it on our deck. A use case a lot of people don't think about... sucking up carpenter bees and wasps. I can suck up those buggers with little risk of getting bit/stung.

This thing is 100% worth the money, so long as it lasts a few more years. My wife has already dropped it a couple times and it's held up just fine so I have faith.

Bonus: even the kids have fun running the vacuum now. It's crazy how just removing a cord from something takes it form being a mundane task to a fun one. Can you tell I really like this thing?

However, our experience quickly soured due to several design flaws. The most frustrating issue is the need to hold down the trigger continuously while vacuuming. This makes using attachments—especially the hose—awkward and uncomfortable. While Dyson claims this feature helps conserve battery life, it feels like the design team may not have considered real-world usage.
To make matters worse, the plastic above the trigger is misaligned and scratches your skin, making extended cleaning sessions unpleasant. We discovered that you can buy an after-market trigger lock, but it’s disappointing to spend this much money and then need additional accessories just to make the vacuum usable.
Compared to our previous $100 vacuum, which included a light and a hardwood floor attachment, this Dyson model falls short. The only way to get a hardwood floor attachment is to purchase another after-market device.
Overall, while we wanted to love this product, the inconvenient trigger mechanism and lack of essential features mean we’ll probably return it. Functionality should not be compromised at this price point

The ever ‘friendly’ Dyson customer service (e.g., “apologize for the inconvenience caused to you” or “appreciate your understanding and patience” etc.) informed me that: "As we checked the proof of purchase the machine is not eligible for a replacement part as we checked the purchase invoice it is written there sold by wacky jacks.” WHO?? First, I never heard of this company, I bought the Dyson from Amazon, as far as I am concerned … but apparently not. The product came from this third-party seller Wacky Jacky in NJ. So, buyer beware who the third-party sellers are!
I’m super disappoint that a) such an expensive equipment broke down so quickly, and b) that Dyson customer service is so bad. They don’t respect the FTC’s (Federal Trade Commission) law which states that “It’s generally not legal for a company to void a warranty or deny coverage simply because a product was purchases from a third-party vendor.” Lawsuits have been won based on that law. Hope Dyson is next. I reported them to ReportFraud.ftc.gov.
Happy ending for me though, after a discussion with the Amazon customer service they eventually agreed to a full return of the product, with a full refund. Thank you, Amazon.
